title: 107_s120
content: The Act may be cited as the "Master Teacher Act of 2001" and includes a Master Teacher Demonstration Project. The Master Teacher Act of 2001 defines a "master teacher" as an experienced educator selected based on excellence and recommendations from administrators and peers. The teacher must be licensed, have at least 5 years of teaching experience, and be currently teaching in a public school. The teacher must be licensed, have at least 5 years of teaching experience, and be currently teaching in a public school. The Secretary of Education will conduct a demonstration project to award grants to increase teacher salaries and benefits for teachers in local educational agencies. The Secretary will award grants to local educational agencies to increase teacher salaries and benefits for master teachers. Grants will be given to agencies of varying sizes, locations, and student demographics, with priority given to those with economically disadvantaged students. Agencies must submit applications to receive grants under the project. The local educational agency must submit an application to the Secretary for a grant under the demonstration project, detailing the use of funds for master teacher salaries and benefits. The agency must also provide matching non-Federal contributions equal to the grant amount. Additionally, a study and report are required as part of the project. The Secretary will conduct a study and submit a report to Congress by July 1, 2005, analyzing the impact of the demonstration project on teacher recruitment, mentoring, and student achievement, along with providing recommendations. Authorization of Appropriations: $100,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2002 through 2006 to continue or expand the demonstration project to additional local educational agencies and school districts.
